issue.title: Request: Change contact reference frame from global to local for msgs::Contact

content.raw:
the way it's currently done is due to the fact that current collision detector returns data in global frame.

An update similar to pull request #336 is needed.  Investigation on performance impact should follow.
content.html:
the way it's currently done is due to the fact that current collision detector returns data in global frame.

An update similar to pull request #336 is needed. Investigation on performance impact should follow.

Request: Change contact reference frame from global to local for msgs::Contact

content.raw: The forces and torques are in the link reference frame as of pull request #355 (though I don't think the contact sensor `<pose>` element is considered). I believe the normal and position are still in the world frame.
content.html: The forces and torques are in the link reference frame as of pull request #355 (though I don't think the contact sensor <pose> element is considered). I believe the normal and position are still in the world frame.

issue.title: Request: Change contact reference frame from global to local for msgs::Contact

content.raw: Issue #540 was marked as a duplicate of this issue.
content.html: Issue #540 was marked as a duplicate of this issue.

issue.title: Request: Change contact reference frame from global to local for msgs::Contact

content.raw: For contact sensors, we should use the sensor frame (contact sensor's parent link frame plus sensor pose tag) for the wrench, position and normal. For other contacts, I'm not sure what is the best thing to do.
content.html: For contact sensors, we should use the sensor frame (contact sensor's parent link frame plus sensor pose tag) for the wrench, position and normal. For other contacts, I'm not sure what is the best thing to do.

issue.title: Request: Change contact reference frame from global to local for msgs::Contact

content.raw:
Contact sensor change sounds good.

The general case should be left in the global frame. Contact info includes the two bodies that collided, so a user can transform the contact point into the frame of their choice.

It might help if we write a tutorial and add more doxygen.
content.html:
Contact sensor change sounds good.

The general case should be left in the global frame. Contact info includes the two bodies that collided, so a user can transform the contact point into the frame of their choice.

It might help if we write a tutorial and add more doxygen.

issue.title: Request: Change contact reference frame from global to local for msgs::Contact

content.raw: Currently all contact wrenches are reported in a body-fixed frame. Maybe we should add a flag to the contact or contacts message to indicate which frame is being used, since it may not be obvious which contact topics are from contact sensors and which are "raw physics".
content.html: Currently all contact wrenches are reported in a body-fixed frame. Maybe we should add a flag to the contact or contacts message to indicate which frame is being used, since it may not be obvious which contact topics are from contact sensors and which are "raw physics".

issue.title: Request: Change contact reference frame from global to local for msgs::Contact

content.raw:
> The general case should be left in the global frame. Contact info includes the two bodies that collided, so a user can transform the contact point into the frame of their choice.

Sure, that is possible. But is it necessary?

I believe it's a common pattern that sensor information is give in the sensor's frame. What's this general case, that sensor information is given in a global frame? To me (robot user/developer) that doesn't sound too useful, as one often doesn't have (precise) information about the robot/sensor's position in the global (world) frame.
content.html:
The general case should be left in the global frame. Contact info includes the two bodies that collided, so a user can transform the contact point into the frame of their choice.

Sure, that is possible. But is it necessary?

I believe it's a common pattern that sensor information is give in the sensor's frame. What's this general case, that sensor information is given in a global frame? To me (robot user/developer) that doesn't sound too useful, as one often doesn't have (precise) information about the robot/sensor's position in the global (world) frame.

issue.title: Request: Change contact reference frame from global to local for msgs::Contact

content.raw:
The issue that @bit-pirate posted is exactly my problem too. It would be great to know the contact point in the sensor/body frame of the robot since the behavior of the robot can be different based on where it makes contact. Is this fixed for the Contact sensor in specific? 

@nkoenig If we had to do the math to transform the contact position from global to robot frame, how we would go about doing this? Is there maybe a document or a general methodology you can point me to? 

Alternatively, how we could've gone about this is to place multiple contact sensors (child of base_link) at different parts of the robot, but unfortunately a contact is not reported by Gazebo if the link is a child of the base_link. So this is not an option either. 

Just tested on Gazebo5 and it looks like it is still in the global frame.
content.html:
The issue that @bit-pirate posted is exactly my problem too. It would be great to know the contact point in the sensor/body frame of the robot since the behavior of the robot can be different based on where it makes contact. Is this fixed for the Contact sensor in specific?

@nkoenig If we had to do the math to transform the contact position from global to robot frame, how we would go about doing this? Is there maybe a document or a general methodology you can point me to?

Alternatively, how we could've gone about this is to place multiple contact sensors (child of base_link) at different parts of the robot, but unfortunately a contact is not reported by Gazebo if the link is a child of the base_link. So this is not an option either.

Just tested on Gazebo5 and it looks like it is still in the global frame.

issue.title: Request: Change contact reference frame from global to local for msgs::Contact

content.raw:
The contact sensor has not been updated yet.

For pose transformations, take a look at the [Pose class](http://osrf-distributions.s3.amazonaws.com/gazebo/api/6.1.0/classgazebo_1_1math_1_1Pose.html).
content.html:
The contact sensor has not been updated yet.

For pose transformations, take a look at the Pose class.

content.raw:
using Gazebo 7.0.0 and kinetic version of gazebo_ros_pkgs
I need to recover the possibility in the gazebo_ros_bumper to get the force/torque/position/normal in a user given frame (for instance link/sensor frame). I found a way to re-activate commented out code https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/blob/kinetic-devel/gazebo_plugins/src/gazebo_ros_bumper.cpp#L146  but then had wrong data in a simple test case. 
This is because the line https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/blob/kinetic-devel/gazebo_plugins/src/gazebo_ros_bumper.cpp#L256 is using a reverse transform to get force from world to desired frame.

From the information contained in this issue, namely force/torque are in sensor frame and position/normal are in global frame, I could understand and fix the behaviour of the gazebo_ros_bumper with a forward transform from link/sensor to world and then a reverse transform to desired frame. All fine.

But then found out another issue. In some cases, the contact.wrench(j).body_1_wrench().force  is not the force of the current sensor, but of the "other" object expressed in its own local link (body 1 is not the sensor collision object). Hence making the transform completely wrong. One needs to select the correct body and apply the correct transform.

@nkoenig says because the collision names are known, so are the body names and one can transform in the frame one likes. The problem I found is how to know which body the sensor is attached to and match it then with the collision name given by the contacts. As far as I know the collision name can be user given in the SDF and could differ from the body name. Unfortunately, the contactsensor part of the SDF where a collision tag is embedded is inaccessible from the plugin (the parent sdf is protected). I might have missed something.
[EDIT]Indeed, I now found a way to access the parent sdf (and so also the collision name), by doing sdf->getParent() ! I was first looking at the sensor only...[\EDIT]

I wanted to comment in this issues as this non-obvious frames (part in link frame, part in global) should be cleared up or settled and self-describing in the messages somehow (the same way as ROS is using PoseStamped containing the frame name) as suggested by @scpeters ?

thanks
content.html:
using Gazebo 7.0.0 and kinetic version of gazebo_ros_pkgs I need to recover the possibility in the gazebo_ros_bumper to get the force/torque/position/normal in a user given frame (for instance link/sensor frame). I found a way to re-activate commented out code https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/blob/kinetic-devel/gazebo_plugins/src/gazebo_ros_bumper.cpp#L146 but then had wrong data in a simple test case. This is because the line https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/blob/kinetic-devel/gazebo_plugins/src/gazebo_ros_bumper.cpp#L256 is using a reverse transform to get force from world to desired frame.

From the information contained in this issue, namely force/torque are in sensor frame and position/normal are in global frame, I could understand and fix the behaviour of the gazebo_ros_bumper with a forward transform from link/sensor to world and then a reverse transform to desired frame. All fine.

But then found out another issue. In some cases, the contact.wrench(j).body_1_wrench().force is not the force of the current sensor, but of the "other" object expressed in its own local link (body 1 is not the sensor collision object). Hence making the transform completely wrong. One needs to select the correct body and apply the correct transform.

@nkoenig says because the collision names are known, so are the body names and one can transform in the frame one likes. The problem I found is how to know which body the sensor is attached to and match it then with the collision name given by the contacts. As far as I know the collision name can be user given in the SDF and could differ from the body name. Unfortunately, the contactsensor part of the SDF where a collision tag is embedded is inaccessible from the plugin (the parent sdf is protected). I might have missed something. [EDIT]Indeed, I now found a way to access the parent sdf (and so also the collision name), by doing sdf->getParent() ! I was first looking at the sensor only...[\EDIT]

I wanted to comment in this issues as this non-obvious frames (part in link frame, part in global) should be cleared up or settled and self-describing in the messages somehow (the same way as ROS is using PoseStamped containing the frame name) as suggested by @scpeters ?

thanks
